Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: there is currently an attacker bringing down nodes on the KMD network, they have taken down the node we query for the ledger rewards claim app

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: this is why it isn't working

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: james has pushed a fix

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I will update and everything should be working again shortly

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: sorry for the inconvenience

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what requests does this server fulfill? is there a way to do it locally?

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: yes, would be better if users could run the claim app locally. @hyperDEX said an app like this might be released a while ago.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: All good now

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: @jl777c @SHossain it's just a standard insight node

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: we just spun up our own instance with generous API limits because BIP44 account discovery requires a lot of requests and all the existing API servers banned us if we tried to use them

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you might consider using libnspv, it supports a similar dataset as insight

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but anyone can run the app locally and point it to their own local insight server or another remote insight server

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: nice

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I'm not familiar with libnspv

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a superlite client

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: can I query by address?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://medium.com/@jameslee777/nspv-a-simple-approach-to-superlight-clients-leveraging-notarizations-75d7ef5a37a9

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://medium.com/@jameslee777/nspv-reference-cli-client-cf1ffdc03631

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://medium.com/@jameslee777/libnspv-evolution-of-nspv-ed157f8b159d

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, it supports addressindex calls

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it even supports mempool queries, rather queries about the mempool

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: nice

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I'm assuming this is talking over the p2p protocol?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: so wouldn't work from a browser without a HTTP proxy?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, using p2p protocol

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i have heard that it builds via wasm, but not familiar with the details

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: that's really cool

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but yeah, you'd still need some sort of browser <=> komodo network bridge

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: even if it builds with wasm it'll likely be using websockets to communicate so it'll be on it's own isolated browser network until a bridge node connects the websocket/komodo networks together

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: where are all the indexes stored?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: do you need special fully indexed full nodes that are indexing all addresses?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: on fullnodes that support it

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: are they indexing everything like insight/electrum?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it uses the same -addressindex that insight explorers are calling

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: insight is just a html front end to the -addressindex calls

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the DB is inside the komodod, not the insight, at least there is no need for a DB at the insight level as the addressindex rpc calls returns all the relevant info

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: that's awesome

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: do you know why addressindex isn't supported in bitcoin core?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: do you know why 4MB blocks arent supported in bitcoin legacy?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even though segwit blocks can be 4MB in size

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: because there wasn't consensus to hardfork to a bigger block size

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: genuinely interested in the reasoning behind `-addressindex` being rejected though

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: why do they deprecate rpc that is universally used?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Cos bitcoin-cli RPC sucks and rather than keep bloating the same methods they add new more specific ones

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: if you don't know the reason why no worries, I just assumed there was some history behind it as I'm sure BitPay tried to get it merged in but Googled and can't find a PR or any more info on it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can try to justify changing how an existing rpc call works and making a different rpc call that worked the way it used to, but really there is no excuse for such breaking of backward compatibility. just make new functionality have new rpc, and dont break the existing
